image.altText: people walking outside a store

items.synopsis: Optus says "changes to routing information" after a "routine software upgrade" was behind last week's nationwide outage, affecting 10.2 million Australians and impacting 400,000 businesses.

title.children: Optus says changes after a 'routine software upgrade' to blame for nationwide service outage

image.altText: A centrelink sign with on a building with a reflection

items.synopsis: The federal government agrees to all of the recommendations of the Robodebt royal commission, as it reveals investigations have commenced into 16 public servants connected to the scheme.

title.children: 'People were traumatised': 16 public servants investigated over doomed Robodebt scheme

image.altText: Helicopter vision of the truck on its side at Horsley Park

items.synopsis: Police say the rental truck was carrying 3,000 litres of stolen diesel fuel when it crashed on a busy Sydney motorway, causing significant delays.

title.children: 'Lucky no one was killed': Two men flee after rolling truck filled with $6,300 of stolen fuel on Sydney motorway

image.altText: a man and a woman both wearing name tags standing outdoors and smiling at the camera

items.synopsis: The lawyer representing receivers tells the Federal Court, the alleged fraudster's second husband, Michael Koletti, has "completely backed down" from various claims over the estate.

title.children: 'Handful of items': Melissa Caddick's husband backs down from number of claims over estate, court told

image.altText: Dwayne Johnstone

items.synopsis: A jury finds a man dubbed Officer A not guilty of the murder of Dwayne Johnstone, who was shackled at the wrists and ankles when he was shot outside Lismore Base Hospital.

title.children: Correctional officer found not guilty escaping inmate's murder

image.altText: Several police seen at a protest rally. There are flags and several uniformed officers.

items.synopsis: Premier Chris Minns says it would not be "unreasonable" for state governments to request financial assistance to cover the cost of managing recent rallies over the ongoing conflict.

title.children: NSW government hopes Commonwealth will help pay for million-dollar police presence at Israel-Gaza protests

image.altText: A blurry image of a woman standing in front of an emergency hospital sign

items.synopsis: NSW spends the least per capita on mental health services than any other state in the country, and experts say the system is in crisis.

title.children: 'It's never been this bad': Why critically ill mental health patients are being turned away in NSW

image.altText: A sign reading CBH Resouces Limited Rasp Mine with mine workers standing in the background

items.synopsis: An uncertain future lies ahead for workers at CBH Resources' Rasp Mine, where some staff have been told today will be their last on site.

title.children: Workers laid off, more jobs cuts likely as Broken Hill mine announces staged shutdown

image.altText: Giles gestures with one hand as he speaks at the despatch box.

items.synopsis: Eighty asylum seekers being held in immigration detention were released almost immediately following last week's High Court ruling that they were being kept unlawfully.

title.children: 80 asylum seekers in immigration detention released 'almost immediately' after High Court ruling

image.altText: A brunette Pakistani woman, a blonde white woman and a dark brunette black woman wearing superhero outfits stand looking skyward

items.synopsis: Marvel Cinematic Universe's latest movie instalment, The Marvels, has had a disappointing opening weekend at the box office, recording $US47 million in sales in the US — the lowest amount the comic book franchise has recorded to date.

title.children: The Marvels has had the MCU's worst opening weekend at the box office. What went wrong?

image.altText: Aerial photo of Bramwell Station in Queensland's Cape York Peninsula.

items.synopsis: Police say the man, who set off from Bramwell Station, was "well prepared" for the fishing trip but note it is a known crocodile habitat.

title.children: Search underway for missing Sydney fisherman in Far North Queensland

image.altText: An employee of DP World walking along the Melbourne wharves

items.synopsis: DP World is a global behemoth in shipping and logistics. But a cyber attack on its Australian operation has crippled some of our busiest ports in the busy lead up to Christmas.

title.children: Freight giant DP World recovers from cyber attack, but warns investigation and remediation is 'ongoing'

image.altText: Close up of medicinal cannabis plant being grown in a farm.

items.synopsis: The first-ever bill to create a legal recreational marijuana market in Australia was lodged in federal parliament earlier this year — but not all cannabis enthusiasts are on board with the proposal to legalise it.

title.children: Why marijuana users are worried corporations will replace drug dealers

image.altText: An artist's impression of a man on a zipwire crossing a canyon.

items.synopsis: An "adventure precinct" slated for the Blue Mountains' Gardens of Stone Conservation Area will no longer be built, but plans for a series of eco-cabins are still moving ahead.

title.children: Plans for Australia's longest zip-line scrapped after community outcry

image.altText: Dozens of women and children sit at the back of a truck, peering through a grid side wall

items.synopsis: Two of northern Gaza's major hospitals say they have closed doors to new patients due to bombardment and lack of supplies, with staff warning patient deaths could follow. Israel says it is homing in on Hamas and the hospitals should be evacuated.

title.children: Hospitals begin to shut down as Israel says it is closing in on Hamas in Gaza City

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli President Isaac Herzog denies Israel is striking Gaza's Al Shifa facility. The largest hospital in Gaza is reportedly sheltering thousands of Palestinians and has run out of fuel. But Mr Herzog says "everything is operating" at the hospital. Speaking to the BBC, he calls the claims "a lot of a spin by Hamas". "We deny this at all, there is a lot of spin by Hamas … but there's electricity in Shifa, everything is operating," Mr Herzog says. The World Health Organization (WHO) said it had lost communication on Saturday with the hospital before it was restored Sunday. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says the hospital situation is "dire and perilous" and that it had been three days without electricity and water. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says water tanks, a cardiovascular facility and the maternity ward have been damaged.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli president denies country is behind strikes on Al Shifa hospital

children.content: Israeli President Isaac Herzog denies Israel is striking Gaza's Al Shifa facility.
The largest hospital in Gaza is reportedly sheltering thousands of Palestinians and has run out of fuel.
But Mr Herzog says "everything is operating" at the hospital.
Speaking to the BBC,
he calls the claims "a lot of a spin by Hamas".
"We deny this at all, there is a lot of spin by Hamas … but there's electricity in Shifa, everything is operating," Mr Herzog says.

props.alt: Man in suit stands on left on Isaac Herzog right.

children.content: Mr Herzog (right) with US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken.
(Reuters: Jonathan Ernst)
The World Health Organization (WHO) said it had lost communication on Saturday
with the hospital before it was restored Sunday.
WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says the hospital situation is "dire and perilous" and that it had been three days without electricity and water.
The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says
water tanks, a cardiovascular facility and the maternity ward
have been damaged.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's prime minister has begun to outline Israel's post-war plans for Gaza. However, they could contrast sharply with the US's vision. Benjamin Netanyahu says he would like to see Gaza would be demilitarised. Israel would retain the ability to enter Gaza freely to hunt down Hamas, he says. Benjamin Netanyahu also rejected the idea the Palestinian Authority, which administers parts of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, would control Gaza. Secretary of State Antony Blinken has previously said the US opposes an Israeli reoccupation of Gaza. The US envisions a unified Palestinian government in Gaza and the West Bank as a step toward a Palestinian state, something long opposed by Mr Netanyahu's government. Reporting with AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No sign of Palestinian Authority control in Netanyahu's post-war plans

children.content: Israel's prime minister has begun to outline Israel's post-war plans for Gaza.
However, they could contrast sharply with the US's vision.
Benjamin Netanyahu says he would
like to see Gaza would be demilitarised.
Israel would retain the ability to enter Gaza freely to hunt down Hamas, he says.
Benjamin Netanyahu also rejected the idea the Palestinian Authority, which administers parts of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, would control Gaza.
Secretary of State Antony Blinken has previously said the US opposes an Israeli reoccupation of Gaza.
The US envisions a unified Palestinian government in Gaza and the West Bank as a step toward a Palestinian state, something long opposed by Mr Netanyahu's government.
Reporting with AP

props.alt: Benjamin Netanyahu looks sternly in front of Israeli flag.

children.content: Benjamin Netanyahu says he would like to retain Israel's ability to enter Gaza freely.
(Reuters )

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier, we shared the World Health Organization's update on the Al Shifa Hospital. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs estimates some 3,000 patients remain trapped in the hospital. They say two premature babies and 10 other patients have died since the power outage that started on November 11. The organisation also claim s three nurses have been killed and an estimated 15,000 displaced people remain in the hospital. Critical infrastructure including the oxygen station, water tanks, a cardiovascular facility and the maternity ward was damaged, the UN's office says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two babies, 10 patients dead in Al Shifa hospital: UN update

children.content: Earlier, we shared the
World Health Organization's update
on the Al Shifa Hospital.
The
United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs estimates
some 3,000 patients remain trapped
in the hospital.
They say
two premature babies and 10 other patients have died
since the power outage that started on November 11.
The organisation also claim
s three nurses have been killed
and an estimated 15,000 displaced people remain in the hospital.
Critical infrastructure including the oxygen station, water tanks, a cardiovascular facility and the maternity ward was damaged, the UN's office says.

image.altText: Concept art showing four warships fanning out in open waters.

items.synopsis: The Defence Department has conceded its process for selecting its $45 billion future frigates, closely overseen by Coalition ministers, was "poorly executed".

title.children: Defence admits 'poorly executed' process in $45 billion future frigate selection

image.altText: people sitting around on top of mound of rubble with few standing buildings visible behind them

items.synopsis: Hamas says it is suspending hostage talks due to Israel's attacks around Al Shifa hospital, as the first group of foreigners and injured Palestinians to be evacuated from Gaza after the Rafah border crossing reopened arrive in Egypt.

title.children: Hamas suspends hostage negotiations due to their claims that Israel is targeting hospitals

image.altText: The silhouette of several people, some holidng Palestinian flags

items.synopsis: Global Palestinian solidarity demonstrations are getting bigger, but whether taking to the streets will make a difference to government policy is up for debate, writes Riley Stuart.

title.children: When the crowd chants 'ceasefire now', this is why some governments remain 'deaf'

image.altText: Screenshot of a video of a lion standing on a street

items.synopsis: Lion handler Rony Vassallo says he personally checked on the cage an hour before the lion went walkabout, and "everything was in order".

title.children: Escaped Italian circus lion 'didn't even for a second' want to attack nearby residents, says trainer

image.altText: Two men in suits shaking hands, Parliament House and $100 notes in the background.

items.synopsis: Identified in Parliament House by their orange access passes, lobbyists are free to wander the halls, governed not by laws but by a code of conduct. But the standard of regulation in the industry has been deplored by both integrity experts and independent politicians.

title.children: In Canberra, the lobbyists outnumber the politicians. One MP is now proposing an overhaul to curb their influence

image.altText: Close up of a man with dairy cows in the background

items.synopsis: Dry conditions across the state has seen farmers making tough decisions to either sell stock or invest heavily in feed to keep animals alive as they wait for rain.

title.children: Farmers destocking as NSW drought conditions worsen

image.altText: A large cruise ship docks at a harbour

items.synopsis: Authorities say there were five cases of gastro on board the ship when it arrived in Adelaide this morning, and eight cases of "COVID-like infection".

title.children: 'Vomit smells everywhere': Cruise ship's COVID, gastro outbreaks over as passengers disembark in Adelaide

image.altText: picture of a polar bear on ice

items.synopsis: A study of a thousand glaciers in the area shows the rate of melting entering a new phase over the last two decades.

title.children: Melting of all Greenland's glaciers 'in full swing' as speed of ice thaw increases fivefold

image.altText: Two adults stand with a child in a wheelchair.

items.synopsis: Organising a trip to Ballarat was no easy task for this Melbourne family because of 12-year-old Anuli's complex needs. When the outing finally happened, it ended in a way that left them "traumatised".

title.children: 'Like a pack of hyenas': Melbourne family shocked after chain hurled at daughter in wheelchair during Ballarat visit

image.altText: Celeste Barber wearing a navy blazer with bright pink patterns stands in front of a wall with the same pattern

items.synopsis: Comedian Celeste Barber is no stranger to the absurdities of the fashion industry, but even she was taken aback to learn the extent to which some clothes – and the women who wore them – were policed in our nation’s past.

title.children: Celeste Barber on Australia's 'uncomfortable' fashion moment

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing a navy suit

items.synopsis: Dr Bush-Blanasi was a champion for Indigenous rights at both the local and national level — most recently as a key campaigner for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Northern Land Council chair Dr Bush-Blanasi dies aged 61

image.altText: O'Neil stands at the despatch box, Anthony Albanese sitting behind her.

items.synopsis: Fearing that telecommunications companies have been left to manage their own cyber affairs with limited oversight, the home affairs minister imposes new reporting obligations in an attempt to prevent another Optus-style hack.

title.children: Optus and other telcos to be forced to report to government on how they manage cybersecurity

image.altText: ANZ

items.synopsis: Australian shares closed lower on Monday, led by a substantial drop in ANZ's share price as its full-year profit misses market forecasts. Look back on the day's developments with our blog.

title.children: ANZ shares smashed as $7.1b profit disappoints, RBA warns of 'bumpy' road to curb inflation, ASX finishes lower — as it happened

image.altText: The woman's hands lie in her lap, she has pink nail polish and wears a leopard-print skirt.

items.synopsis: The woman who was choked by Tongan man Seti Moala in April last year speaks of the trauma she experienced both during the attack and again as the case went to trial.

title.children: This woman was choked by a man in a Canberra motel room. She says she wasn't given a fair trial

image.altText: A young woman with dark, curly hair stands with her fist raised in an art gallery.

items.synopsis: Multimedia artist Roberta Joy Rich uses family memories and archival news footage to ask deep questions about the impact of apartheid policies in South Africa and Australia.

title.children: Art exhibition links apartheid with colonial Australia in Perth show

image.altText: A photo which shows Gove refinery from the air. Gove Operations is located on the Gove Peninsula in North East Arnhem land.

items.synopsis: The High Court will hold a special hearing in Darwin next year in a challenge over a $700 million compensation claim over land acquired for aluminium mining in north-east Arnhem Land in the 1960s.

title.children: High Court heads to Darwin as Commonwealth challenges $700m native title compensation claim

image.altText: Alex's mum believes the ward's environment is not therapuetic

items.synopsis: An alleged violent altercation between a patient and one or more security guards that left other vulnerable patients shaken again puts safety at Perth Children's Hospital under the spotlight.

title.children: Investigation launched after alleged violent altercation at children's hospital leaves patients scared

image.altText: Sam Kerr gets in front of a defender to prod the ball home

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr ends a quiet spell for Chelsea by getting back to her familiar prolific ways with a second goal of the Women's Super League season in their win at Everton.

title.children: Sam Kerr and Caitlin Foord score crucial goals in England on memorable day for Matildas stars

image.altText: Eggplants crushed on the ground under a fallen metal structure.

items.synopsis: Farmers are calling for assistance to rebuild infrastructure and replant crops, with the impact on the supply of fruit and vegetables unclear at the moment.

title.children: Farmers pick up the pieces after a wild hail storm causes an estimated $50 million in losses

image.altText: a cricketer bowling

items.synopsis: The cricket gods have smiled on a club bowler after he bagged six wickets in the final over of a one-day match to snatch a miracle victory for his team.

title.children: Gold Coast captain makes cricket history by taking six wickets in six balls in unbelievable last-over win
